course.subject: CIVL
course.name: Aquatic Chemistry
course.description: Chemistry applied to reactions occurring in water and wastewater, includes inorganic solution chemistry, chemical equilibrium, acids/bases, coordination chemistry, chemical kinetics, colloid chemistry, solubility and precipitation, oxidation-reduction potential.

reviews.author: shirayuki653
reviews.title: Chem for civil students
reviews.comment_content:
Basically this course is introduction to physical and analytical chemistry(CHEM 1030,2311,2410). This course aimed to provide students a science background for their research/ FYP. Fundamental knowledge in chemistry is recommended before taking this course, CIVL2410 is not a hard prerequisite since technical part is barely covered.

The topics should more or less same in every semester, they are pretty standard and you can go goggling for them.  
1. Introduction
2. Chemical kinetics
3. Chemical equilibrium
4. Acids/bases
5. Colloid chemistry
6. Solubility and precipitation
7. Redox Reactions

I take this course as a CIEV elective and I think the content is not hard to understand, since I am OK in chemistry. Also, the content is good enough for students to understand/evaluate the techniques for water treatment processes.

Moreover, this semester is in online delivery mode due to the pandemic so the comments may not be accurate enough.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The PowerPoint slides are easy to read and go through (I think they are complementary ones from the textbook). The instructor is enthusiastic but not energetic. Although he can explain the concepts quite well, but it is easy to fall asleep with his flat tone. . During the lectures, he will ask some questions as to take attendance. Comparatively, his teaching is better than 4430 I think.

The lecture is 3 hours long per week and it is conducted at night to fit the schedule of RPG students (7-10 pm this year), and a short break will be provided between.2/3 are RPG and the rest are UG students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Professor said that mean grades will turn out a B+/A-, normal for PG courses and of course lenient for UG students

Grading scheme:
5% attendance
10% homework, full mark for submission
40% midterm (cancelled this semester)
45% final (85% this semester with the cancellation of midterm)
I screw up my final since I miss 10 pts out of 100
Finally B, so good grade!

Please be remind that to write down all the things he said in the lecture or else you will have a miserable life like me
reviews.comment_workload:
Not high
Just 3-4 question for each homework, and  have a week to finish it. It is not bad for treat them as exercises.
Then remaining workload is to understand the slides and try to master them

reviews.author: Kendric
reviews.comment_content: Course content is foundational and relevant to research and also to enriching the understanding of other courses such was wastewater treatment
reviews.comment_teaching:
Notes and solutions to the assignments are detailed.

When deemed necessary, there is an effort to show pen and paper solutions to some problem types.

Given the length of the class (approximately 3 hours) and the schedule (evenings), there are also some breaks given at the halfway mark

However accent can be difficult to understand at times
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments are given 100% as long as they are submitted on-time

Exam is graded according to PG grading
reviews.comment_workload:
1 assignment at the end of every chapter to be submitted weekly

1 final exam

reviews.author: ljdjlalb
reviews.title: Ug perspective on reviewing 5439
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are very relevant research study in environmental engineering as it focuses on finding the fraction of a species for a given reaction in different pH.

It is also useful for the civil3420 content. As it revises concepts mentioned in 3420. Highly recommend taking both course at the same time.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His tone is flat and accent requires some time to adapt with.

But the lecture notes provided is rich in content and easy to understand.

He is also passionate in teaching. I would say I love this professor.

Btw he does boost about his publication on nature water this year. Very funnnyyyyyyy. He has literally a smiley face throughout the whole class.
reviews.comment_workload:
7 homework assignments. Marking with regards to your due diligence. Very generous I would say.

1 final exam. If you go through all examples in the lecture notes, you would properly know how to solve questions possibly appear in the exam. As the technique required to solve the questions are limited (6-7 at most).

reviews.author: cheese
reviews.title: Normal Course
reviews.comment_content: The first three chapters are very easy to understand if you have learnt chemistry in high school. The hard part is Chapters 4 to 6 which requires you to calculate the concentration of up to 10 substance by 10 equations.
reviews.comment_teaching: The notes are a bit hard to understand and therefore dropping notes is essential. Though, the accent of the professor is very difficult to listen to. Sometimes, he may make some mistakes. And he may also pick someone to answer questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
I am only taking this course to fulfill my graduation requirement as a UG student and the professor already says that all UG students will be granted Grade B or above (and you are allowed to apply for P/F grade due to COVID-19)

All homework must be graded full marks if you have handed in.
Homework 100%
Attendance <100% (Attended each lesson but forgot to pay attention when he asked me questions)
Exam, scores not released, quite similar to homework and referring to notes.
Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload: Little, due to the pandemic and the online teaching mode. No midterms. Only online open-book exam. The homework must be done once a week, but you don't need to answer them correctly. You just need to show that you have tried working on it, and you will get full marks. There is 7 homework roughly, and 2-4 questions each.
